item.content:encoded:
Fake and Gay Economy

Open thread • Replies: 29 • Updated: 2026-02-19 05:47 UTC

OP

When will this gay as economy finally collapse and how can i profit from it?
Its ridiculous the woman at our workplace contribute nothing to the company and make more money than i do
Its infuriating we just had a bunch of lay offs and we lost some of oir best workers but somehow a bunch of HR shits who do nothing all day still work here

Early replies (first 3)

61871530
HR is a necessary function, chud

61871569
>>61871530
For what?
Genuinely why do we need it to this extent?

61871755
>>61871569
Protect the corp from lawsuits

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61871931
>OP is letting an australian skincare companies satire social media post bother him enough to make a post about it.
anon they saw you get pissed off on their first vid and are just continuing a bit. they don't ACTUALLY do nothing. they are a marketing team. and you are a shill promoting their content. you are more fake and gay than they are.

61871937
>>61871569
Benefits is needed to keep people from leaving and to entice new applicants. HR is needed because of what >>61871755 said. The part of hr that does need to be eradicated is the hiring team. HR is sadly needed but they put in a bunch of bullshit. HR is a reflection of the legal system because they are only there to make sure the company doesn't go bankrupt from getting sued out the ass. Make the courts and judges less gay and then you can downsize HR because the risk isn't as high.

61871939
>>61871520
>this is a good dance, a skillful execution of dance moves.

61871942
>>61871520
Yes, we sent rejection emails out from Workday 1 day later.
Yes, we still pay to promote that position 4 months later.
Yes, Santa should have wrapped that LinkedIn posting.
Yes, Santa sent it early.

61871955
One last thing. LinkedIn and Indeed are fucking retarded for not forcing companies to pay to post their job postings.
>Ensures the job postings are actually legit
>Additional revenue source
>Insider knowledge on the industries ACTUALLY hiring

61872023
>>61871937
We require a totally new system with a totally new framework for law.

it will not collapse
money is infinite and keeping adults inside a daycare doing paperwork is easier than having a massive restructuring of modern society that would likely be met with resistance and bloodshed
the difference is that now agents will do the work and humans will pick colors and do even more menial pretend-work

61872072

>>61871937
>>61871955

ai will replace the hr roastie and society will return to the norm. /thread

61872076
>>61872053
Probably yes - it's amazing how complete bullshit most modern white collar jobs are. Literally pushing numbers around a spreadsheet or creating some powerpoint slides.

I make stuff for technical committees and even the Board but have to constantly "dumb things down" so they can understand a super complex thing from one slide. Or make stuff that I KNOW no one will read. Like okay...

You would think in a capitalist system this inefficiency would not exist, but here we are.

61872085
>>61872076
We dont live in capitalist system

Its been state capitalism for long time

61872087
>>61872076
This is a fiat problem, not a capitalism problem.

61872170

The purpose of HR is to protect the company. Putting a retarded and narcisstic Stacy in and having her railroad, gaslight, and demoralize employees, is her primary objective. Think of it as internal forced arbitration

yes
but then she will just be hired to do something even more worthless
that will pay even more

61872195

>where the corporations control the government
>and steal all the the money via bail outs and money printing

thats not capitalism

61872429

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

You don't even read.

61867738

61867859

61867922
>>61864598

>substitution script edits the address on your clipboard for one with a similar start and end so it's visually indistinguishable unless you spend a minute verifying each address against eachother
>gangpreet patel and his village get the capital to send another invader to your country
This isn't a joke btw, there are scripts which manipulate your clipboard like that, and it's even possible for them to be injected into innocent websites via ads. Be careful if you copy/paste addresses anon.

61867928
>>61864463
>gf/wife
I have neither, so I am safe there.

61868014
>>61867922
yeah which is why you do your business on a computer that is only used for BTC and exchanges, and on Linux
if you can't do this you're brown, its effortless

reasonable
>and on linux
javascript can manipulate what goes into your clipboard when you copy or cut, being on linux wont change that.

61868340

61868350

Let me tell you how much my SILVER is worth today :)" like every other silverfag so that everyone everywhere knew he had a bunch of silver bars at his house waiting to be stolen
NOBODY knows about my gold. It lives in a tin under a floorboard. If people ask me about investments I just say it's too complicated for me and I don't understand it.

61868620

61868888

61869243
>>61868620

61871637
>>61863917
Admitted semi-retard here
I was considering putting some of my crypto gains into gold stored in a Swiss vault overseas - not as an investment with expected profit, but just to hold as a hedge against possible doomsday scenarios where any fiat/crypto that I would have chosen to hold instead, suddenly loses all value
Obviously the Swiss vault should have better security measures than most home security systems. But are there any reasons I'm not seeing why I shouldn't do this (besides paying a storage fee)?

61871660
>>61871637
>taking your effortlessly stored asset and converting it into an IOU for a piece of metal in a vault on the other side of the planet
I swear if BTC doesn't catch on and we go back to a metal standard I am torturing you niggers to death in WW3, you are all so retarded.
But let me make this really simple for you, in case you are somehow willing to listen:
If you want to hedge for a doomsday scenario, your only bet is to have a productive farm, a community that respects you and depends on you, lots of guns and ammunition, and maybe a cellar full of preserved goods especially coffee and cigarettes. If you've read about any fucking situation where shit hits the fan, that's pretty much the only thing you can do. Your metal IOU is worthless, your vault of metal is worthless, your Bitcoin is worthless, your property rights are worthless without guns, and your guns are worthless without a community that actually wants you alive and is willing to fight for and or with you.

item.title: Me do asset management & financial planning for a living AMAA — 27 replies — 78.4/hr
item.content:encoded:
Me do asset management & financial planning for a living AMAA

Open thread • Replies: 27 • Updated: 2026-02-19 05:27 UTC

OP

Me do asset management & financial planning for a living AMAA

Early replies (first 3)

61872440
>>61872433
Looks boring af. How haven't you kys'd yourself yet?

61872446
>he doesnt trade his own money to become a player of the game like his clients

61872467
For someone with 200k to invest, what would you do? I’m thinking of a split between SPYI, QQQI, O, and SCHD.

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61872468
>>61872440
I like my job and get paid decently. Most find it boring probably but I like it. I have great coworkers and OK work/life balance

>>61872446
I'm allowed to invest to ya know

61872477
>>61872433
How does it feel knowing you'd be out of a job of the average person wasn't retarded?

61872480
>>61872468
Good for you then. It's important to like one's job. I'm just a house painter, lmao. I like to paint. Make decent money, probably less than you, but enough to live a good life.

61872489
What is all that gay shit on the screen, just put 100% on a global ETF/index fund and be done with it. Your job shouldnt exist.

61872494
>>61872477
Beat me to it

61872500
>>61872468
>I'm allowed to invest to ya know
>please report all investments 30days in advance and we will review before allowing you to do so or denying your request
if you don't admit you have to do this, you are breaking the law

61872526
>>61872477
Oh be nice. (also, have you met the average person?)

>>61872480
Actually sounds peaceful, good on ya. I miss blue collar sometimes desu, it was more tangible than what I do now.

>>61872489
It's a bunch of stuff that moves in different directions than the US stock market and shows their risk/return profiles. It's important if you don't want to get fucked by regime changes.

US market has had a good run for about 15 years, but that doesn't mean it will continue to. Foreign stocks are beating the everloving fuck out of US stocks this year so for for example.

>>61872500
You're a little off on the regulatory requirements there, and you get around it by trading non-reportable securities (boring shit aka mutual funds).

Correct that I have to literally ask my compliance department every time I want to trade a stock/etf/closed-end fund/any other "reportable security" though.

Shit sucks, which is why I'm mostly mutual funds now.

61872546
>>61872526
Im just messin with you anon. Im also trying to diversify from the world etf i have with other uncorrelated assets because it is to concentrated at the top right now.

61872561
>>61872546
You went full VT or something like that?

If so, I personally hate the classic investment-grade bond angle. The class risk/return profile and total return is garbage but I guess that's mostly due to recent interest rate risk consequences and us bouncing off 0% interest rates. If anything, I do short-term like BSV. I have an upcoming house down payment all in a mutual fund equivalent of BSV right now.

The ones a really like are a mix of low or even negative correlation to equities. Gold (GLD) and cat bonds (ILS, very new) are my favorites. Moderate correlation but very high return are some actively managed sovereign EM bond funds, infrastructure funds, and honestly leveraged junk bond funds if you can accept a like .7 correlation and fuckloads of volatility. Bitcoin is hilarious too if you consider it a class, I do. IBIT is my personal fav for it.

If I had to choose 3 to diversify against a black swan event
BSV
GLD
ILS

IBIT would be nice too if you can buy this trough, I'm expecting like $40k or something end of this year/early next year.

61872570
>>61872561
I'll add cat bonds are literally correlated to NOTHING but were hard to access before. ILS is groundbreaking. It should average 6-8% CAGR.

Gold is of course the classic crisis hedge, usually around 8% CAGR depending on what timer period you look at. It will do nothing for a decade then just moon mission.

All the "moderate" correlation stuff I mentioned is usually around 0.4-0.6 correlation to S&P 500.

61872573
What happens when all the boomers cash out their 401ks?

61872582
>>61872433
Whats an aceptable portfolio sharpe?

61872587
>>61872573
The largest wealth transfer in history. I think that long term care facilities are going to milk that demographic hard as fuck. They charge like $500k entry fee and $10k a month at most CCRCs.

I'm long lots of nursing homes/home care stocks as a result lol. Dark ig, but I'm here to make $ not save the world. Some I like (in order):
>CTRE
>ADUS
>ENSG
>WELL

61872593
>>61872433
Help, I got 2 questions but I'm retarded.

I just discovered the Saver's Credit for taxes was a thing and I'm so broke that I actually qualify for the 10% of my contribution credit rate. Is there like a formula to min-max this shit? Currently expecting to make ~$32.2k (AGI) for 2026 but I am only putting in $400 a month into a traditional 401k.

Also, would I be retarded to take out a 5 year, $10k loan @ 9.5 APR to buy LINK? I plan to stake in the pool and HODL for no less than 5 years, probably much longer. Would the opportunity cost be such that it's better to throw that ~$210 a month into retirement instead? It's literally fun money I cannot use for fun anymore so I dunno what to do with it and I got 35 years left wageslaving.

61872614
>>61872582
I always benchmark the S&P 500, which long-term has a sharpe just short of 1. Depends a lot on what period you look at of course.

Risk-adjusted returns are one way to look at a portfolio, but I also like to look at raw standard deviations and correlations. If an asset class has a decent (relative to S&P 500 always for me) CAGR I consider it. I consider a lot more if the correlation to the S&P 500 is low. This balancing act is why I kinda hate treasuries as a class.

I don't really give a shit about volatility if the CAGR is high and correlations are low of all the holdings. It means a smoother, consistent, strong ride up in all environments (stocks go down but my gold rallies hard af and my cat bonds do nothing). Just how I operate. I rebalance a portfolio of mostly gold, bitcoin, equities, and cat bonds once or twice a year.

61872637
>>61872614
What do you look for correlation-wise when building a portfolio? inverse correlation? a gradient distribution (variety)?

61872644
>>61872593
>I just discovered the Saver's Credit for taxes...
Taxes are so complicated that projections like that require specialized software to min/max. The short answer is you'll get a ~$480 credit on your taxes for the 401k contributions. Works for Roth IRA contributions as well btw, which has a lot of flexibility around taking the money out early. Roth is generally better for low income too, I'd say check with your 401k plan and make sure you're capturing the company match and see if they let you contribute as Roth.

>Also, would I be retarded to take out a 5 year, $10k loan @ 9.5 APR to buy LINK?
Probably not the best idea because it's hard to beat a probable 9% interest rate (aka return) hurdle. I'm ignorant about how LINK works though I only care about Monero and BTC for crypto.

61872698
>>61872637
Mostly inverse correlation to S&P and total historical return of the class.

After that it's risk adjusted return and correlation to other assets in the portfolio. The pic in my OP is kind of looking at that, was some quick DD I was doing with data I pulled to build a correlation matrix. Used a lot of tickers as proxies for classes in a pinch. Not a good time period since it was so short, only 10 years, and 2022 threw a LOT of data off for fixed income because of how fast we increased rates. Here's 26 years of data (I prefer 30 then also looking through regimes back to '71 but the data just isn't there for a lot of these).

I like seeing at LEAST 6% historical CAGR more preferably 8%. Then I want it to have a low (<0.3) or negative correlation to the growth engine (S&P 500). Gold is an oddly great choice for this, but I don't go over 10% overall because of the very flat periods gold has historically.

For each asset class there's the give/take of CAGR vs volatility vs correlation and some asset classes just are better than others objectively. Then there's a handful that when you put them together they just work really well because they all move in different directions but trend strongly up long-term.

61872716
interesting thread, ty anon

61872888
>>61872526
>US market has had a good run for about 15 years, but that doesn't mean it will continue to. Foreign stocks are beating the everloving fuck out of US stocks this year so for for example.
that's why he said global ETF

honestly abusing correlation seems only worth it if the assets have an equal return to stocks, all this junk has such low return even if its negatively correlated you're not going to get a free reduction in variance with it without killing your return. That's why i heard some paper showed its optimal to just go 100% stocks. Even if your a boomer, bonds aren't really worth it, you can just adjust your spending if theres a downturn and still come out ahead.

Trying to finds stocks/etfs that are weakly correlated seems to be the play.

61872998
>>61872888
There are a lot of assets that meet or beat equity markets with CAGR and are low correlation. Some are right in the data here >>61872698

Gold for example has a higher average annual return, better risk adjusted return, and a 0.1 correlation.

61873012
>>61872467
All on btc shorts. Outperform those gay indexes for the next three years in one week

61873080
>>61872467
Why do you focus on yield so much instead of total returns?

It's a lot of US large cap equity exposure with tax inefficiency if it's in a taxable account. You'll get big dividend though.

I like PTY, ASGI, etc for yield personally.

61873145
>>61872998
no it fucking doesn't, in the last 110 years it has returned 5% while the stock market returned 10%

>The whole things is never EVER blaming people for going into debt, but blaming companies instead
If one person goes into unsustainable debt, it's a character flaw and they need to fix it themselves. If companies have significant influence on economic policy, blaming companies for this structural issue is valid.

The thing is in 2014, 2017, 2021 you could take 10,000 bucks and buy basically anything and a 10x was guaranteed.

I remember taking 2021 for granted lol.

The 2024 bull run saw an initial pump from alts from january to april and then htey just bled from april to september, then bled again from december to may, and from may 2025 to present the bulk of alts bled out.

I remember seeing microstrategy and I was like "gonna buy that when bitcoin goes back to 50k". Then I saw MSTX. Hell yeah, double your money for each MSTR move, and MSTR was double bitcoin. A run to 100k from 50k would be an easy 8x. And it was. But I sold before the election and fumbled it. The fumbler. It's easy to create a perfect plan in your mind, and watch it play out exactly as you said it would, but it takes a lot of conviction to not fuck it up.

Now most markets are way up. 2026, 2022, 2018, midterm years have slow market growth. The time to buy it was 2023, the time to make it was 2024, the time to swap into alts like KTA and HYPE and AVANTIS was 2025. I called everything correctly but fucked up the one thing that mattered- buying, and holding to a 10x.

item.title: why would anyone live here — 29 replies — 29.8/hr
item.content:encoded:
why would anyone live here

Open thread • Replies: 29 • Updated: 2026-02-19 04:49 UTC

OP

i recently moved to NYC to work for a "lucrative salary" (not really, because this place drains you of all your income) and after working here for 4 months i dont know why anyone would willingly live here

>the entire city smells like rotting shit, cigarette buds and dead animals, not a faint smell, an extremely strong odor that you'll eventually just become nose blind to

>homeless people, fucking everywhere, when i left my apartment there were homeless people sleeping in the hallways of my complex, when you go on walk there are homeless people sleeping on the sidewalk with a PILLOW and BLANKET while regular people walk over them like this is just some normal fucking occurrence (and in this shithole it is) never ever have i seen some shit like this even in the worst of cities ive lived in.

>heroin needles, weed bags, cigarette buds & the occasional dildo just scattered across the city sidewalks, your constantly walking over human shit, broken bottles or dime bags

>rats and rodents EVERYWHERE. il never forget the time i bought a pizza from one of the disgusting street vendors and when i sat down at a table one of the rats were circling my feet trying to climb my leg for a bite.

>the "public transport" system is a just permanent housing for the mentally ill, every time i had to ride the subway i was scared for my life because of all the fucking looneys that inhabit the train systems

this is just off the top of my head, but i think the biggest mindfuck of it all is that its EXPENSIVE to live here its gonna cost you not 50k, not 100k, not 200k, to live comfortably by yourself you need 250K yearly in manhattan. 250k, to live among violent homeless people, 250k to constantly have to walk in rotting shit and roadkill. 250k to have your ears blown out by car horns & niggerbabble, 250k to be forced to smell the most putried scents imaginable i dont know why anyone sane would live here, this place is some sort of social experiment, some sort of anonmoly.

One day one of my coworkers sets me up on a blind date with one of his girlfriend's friends, so we went in as two couples. After dinner, we walk past a "street market" where all the burglars set what they'd stolen out on the sidewalk and people could buy all the stolen property. We get back to the car and some guy in a business suit has unzipped and is pissing on my front right car tire (it's ok, it was a rental). Why there? Why not piss on the sidewalk or on the street or on the wall of a building near him? I dunno, car tire is a perfectly fine place to take a piss, that's what he was in the mood for, so whaddayagonnado, just fugheddabouddit.

NYCers are all fucking insane.

You mean making?

If you were only making 150k then I'm completely unsurprised you felt like a bitter poorfag in NYC. I make that much in a medium/low cost city in the Midwest and feel like I could use a lot more.

If you moved there for a career and only made that much then yeah I think you weren't anywhere close to making an optimal move.

All I'm saying is you're a.) soft as fuck and b.) not nearly as intelligent or valuable as you think you are

The chud memes are exaggerated, but the economic reality for the vast majority of people is that living in a major metro is basically impossible unless you live like a fucking rat with a hald dozen roommates. Big cities are full of rich people not because that's how you get rich and make connections, but because they're the only ones that can afford to live there. And the wealth and connections come naturally, when you have lots of rich people together. Big cities are effectively playgrounds for the top 20%, and open air prisons for the rest who work 3 wagie jobs and still can't afford rent or utilities and live to serve their rich masters.

If you're already rich then you're right: nothing beats a major primary city. More contacts and networking, more opportunities, more fun, more wage slaves to pleasure you. Secondary and tertiary, smaller cities are potentially good for middle income people.
